Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.
        Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing using the following news titles and content. Closely follow how CNBC techcheck chooses context to put into the script, the langauge style and sentence structure. Use the same beginning and ending(including mentioning host Wall-E and Tuesday April 15), and replace CNBC techcheck briefing to 'AI briefing' 
 ""

Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for tuesday, april 15th. microsoft has announced its latest quarterly earnings, reporting a significant increase in revenue driven by strong demand for its cloud computing services. the company's azure platform has seen a 30% year-over-year increase in revenue, bolstering microsoft's position in the competitive cloud market. analysts note this growth comes as businesses continue to shift operations online, further highlighting the importance of cloud infrastructure.

meta, the parent company of facebook, is facing new scrutiny as the european union has imposed a substantial fine for alleged data privacy violations. the €1.2 billion penalty stems from claims that meta mishandled user information, breaching gdpr regulations. the fine is one of the largest ever imposed for data privacy issues, reflecting the growing regulatory pressure tech giants face in global markets.

in other news, alphabet's waymo has expanded its autonomous vehicle testing program in san francisco, now allowing additional riders to use its self-driving taxi service. this move is part of the company's broader strategy to accelerate the deployment of autonomous technology in urban settings. waymo's efforts are closely watched as the race to commercialize self-driving cars intensifies.

finally, shares of netflix soared today after the streaming giant reported more than five million new subscribers in the last quarter. the increase is attributed to the success of recent original content releases, which have captivated audiences worldwide. netflix continues to invest heavily in content creation to maintain its competitive edge in the streaming wars.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
"i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for tuesday, april 15th.

let's kick off with microsoft. the tech giant has reported its latest quarterly earnings and the numbers are impressive. microsoft's revenue has seen a significant uptick, largely driven by robust demand for its cloud computing services. the azure platform, a key player in microsoft’s cloud strategy, experienced a 30% year-over-year revenue increase. analysts highlight the fact that as businesses continue to migrate operations online, the need for solid cloud infrastructure has never been more crucial, cementing microsoft's competitive position in this sector.

turning to meta, the parent company of facebook is under the microscope once more. the european union has slapped meta with a hefty €1.2 billion fine, citing alleged mishandling of user information in violation of gdpr regulations. this penalty is one of the largest ever for data privacy breaches, underscoring the intensifying regulatory landscape global tech companies must navigate.

now, on to waymo. alphabet’s self-driving car unit is expanding its autonomous vehicle testing in san francisco. they've opened up their self-driving taxi service to more riders in the city. this move aligns with waymo's broader goal of accelerating autonomous technology deployment in urban centers, a space closely watched as the race toward self-driving car commercialization heats up.

lastly, let's look at netflix. the streaming behemoth has seen its shares soar today, following a report of over five million new subscribers last quarter. the influx is largely credited to a string of successful original content releases, captivating global audiences. to maintain its edge in the cutthroat streaming market, netflix continues to pour resources into new content development.

that's all for today. we’ll be back with more tech updates tomorrow."
Podcast Title: EP-257 Microsoft's Cloud Surge ☁️, Meta’s Gdpr Fine 📉, Waymo's Expansion in Sf 🚘
Podcast Description:
welcome to wall-e's tech briefing for tuesday, april 15th! explore today's top tech stories:

  • microsoft's quarterly success: impressive revenue growth fueled by strong demand for cloud services, with azure experiencing a 30% year-over-year revenue increase.
  • meta's eu fine: meta faces a massive €1.2 billion fine from the european union for gdpr violations, highlighting the growing regulatory challenges for global tech companies.
  • waymo's expansion in san francisco: alphabet's self-driving unit broadens its autonomous vehicle testing, opening its taxi service to more riders in the city.
  • netflix's subscriber surge: a report of over five million new subscribers last quarter boosts netflix shares, driven by successful original content releases.

stay tuned for tomorrow's tech updates!
Image Prompt: a cohesive podcast cover image featuring a vibrant, futuristic cityscape at twilight. in the foreground, digital clouds hover above the skyline, representing microsoft's cloud surge, glowing with a spectrum of colors to depict data transfer and connectivity. beneath the clouds, a network of illuminated roads in san francisco lines the cityscape, where an array of autonomous waymo vehicles seamlessly navigate the streets. nearby, the iconic silhouette of the golden gate bridge is visible in the distance. above this scene, a digital sphere represents the gdpr, cracked and with binary code flowing out, symbolizing meta’s fine and regulatory challenges. the elements blend smoothly, illustrating the interconnected and dynamic nature of technological evolution and challenges in the modern world
